content:
lass="word-wrap-span">Permanent lass="word-wrap-span">Record. By Edward Snowden. lass="word-wrap-span">Pan class="word-wrap-slass="word-wrap-span">Pan">Metropolitanlass="word-wrap-span">Pan> lass="word-wrap-span">Pan class="word-wrap-slass="word-wrap-span">Pan">Boolass="word-wrap-span">Pan>ks; 352 pages; $30. lass="word-wrap-span">Pan lass="word-wrap-span">Pan class="word-wrap-slass="word-wrap-span">Pan">Macmillanlass="word-wrap-span">Pan>; £20

lass="word-wrap-span">SPIES DO lass="word-wrap-span">NOT usually want to be famous. lass="word-wrap-span">But in 2013 Edward Snowden, then 30 years old, briefly became one of the best-known people in the world. lass="word-wrap-span">Living in a hotel room in lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong, working with journalists and armed with reams of documents belonging to the lass="word-wrap-span">National lass="word-wrap-span">Security lass="word-wrap-span">Agency (NSA), lass="word-wrap-span">America’s main electronic-spying organisation, he laid bare that lass="word-wrap-span">Agency's efforts to build a system of enormous, lass="word-wrap-span">indiscriminate, global surveillance.

lass="word-wrap-span">Now living in exile in lass="word-wrap-span">Russia, Mr Slass="word-wrap-span">Nowden’s lass="word-wrap-span">autobiography is an account of how he became the world’s most famous secret agent. It is well-written, lass="word-wrap-span">frequently funny, and suffers from one glaring omission. lass="word-wrap-span">Even so, in a world much more lass="word-wrap-span">attuned to the downsides of digitisation than it was in 2013, it offers a useful reminder of the god-like omniscience that digital data can lass="word-wrap-span">bestow on those with the power to collect it all.

Mr Snowden was lass="word-wrap-span">One of lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">facilitators of that omniscience. An ordinary childhood was marked by two things. lass="word-wrap-span">One was lass="word-wrap-span">The arrival of lass="word-wrap-span">The internet in its original, pre-corporate form, lass="word-wrap-span">The version which inspired lass="word-wrap-span">The utopian dreaming that surrounded technology in lass="word-wrap-span">The 1990s. lass="word-wrap-span">The olass="word-wrap-span">Ther was his family’s long tradition of government civil service. His falass="word-wrap-span">Ther was in lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Coast lass="word-wrap-span">Guard; his molass="word-wrap-span">Ther worked for a time as an NSA lass="word-wrap-span">administrator.

lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">September 11th attacks inspired Mr Snowden to join up, he writes. lass="word-wrap-span">But his brief stint in lass="word-wrap-span">The army was ended by a training injury. lass="word-wrap-span">While he was convalescing, he decided to put his technical abilities in service of an lass="word-wrap-span">American intelligence community traumatised by its lass="word-wrap-span">inability to prevent lass="word-wrap-span">The attacks. As part of lass="word-wrap-span">The merry-go-round of private lass="word-wrap-span">contractors to whom much of lass="word-wrap-span">America’s electronic intelligence work has been farmed out, Mr Snowden’s role as a systems lass="word-wrap-span">administrator and computing whizz let him see virtually everything lass="word-wrap-span">The spy agencies were doing.

lass="word-wrap-span">The more he learned, lass="word-wrap-span">The more uncomfortable he became. Mr Snowden does not spend many pages describing lass="word-wrap-span">The various surveillance systems he lass="word-wrap-span">disclosed—which, after all, were widely reported at lass="word-wrap-span">The time. lass="word-wrap-span">But his descriptions of lass="word-wrap-span">The real impact of those systems—stripped of lass="word-wrap-span">abstract concepts and technical lass="word-wrap-span">jargon—are some of lass="word-wrap-span">The most disturbing parts of lass="word-wrap-span">The book.

He describes XKEYSCORE, a sort of private search engine fuelled by the NSA’s spying efforts. It allows analysts, operating with little oversight, to view at will the private lass="word-wrap-span">emails, chats, images, and files of almost anyone with an internet connection, up to and including lass="word-wrap-span">Supreme lass="word-wrap-span">Court justices and the president himself. He describes watching an lass="word-wrap-span">Indonesian engineer through the webcam of his lass="word-wrap-span">computer, as the man’s infant son sat on his lap and batted at the keyboard. Mr Snowden calls XKEYSCORE as “the lass="word-wrap-span">closest thing to science fiction I’ve ever seen”. lass="word-wrap-span">Employees of the NSA, he says, saw it in less lass="word-wrap-span">elevated terms: one popular pastime was to use it for “LOVEINT”, rifling through the online lives of former or potential lovers—cyber-stalking lass="word-wrap-span">backed by the full power of a modern intelligence agency. lass="word-wrap-span">Intercepted nudes, he says, were an office currency.

lass="word-wrap-span">The press, he notes, mostly missed a story that was squatting right out in lass="word-wrap-span">The open. lass="word-wrap-span">Why else would lass="word-wrap-span">The NSA build what was originally called lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">massive lass="word-wrap-span">Data lass="word-wrap-span">Repository, a lass="word-wrap-span">colossal lass="word-wrap-span">Data-storage lass="word-wrap-span">facility in lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Utah desert? He lass="word-wrap-span">cites an unclassified presentation given by lass="word-wrap-span">Ira lass="word-wrap-span">Hunt, lass="word-wrap-span">Then lass="word-wrap-span">The chief technologist at lass="word-wrap-span">The CIA, in which he blilass="word-wrap-span">Thely told a crowd of conference lass="word-wrap-span">attendees and journalists that “it is nearly within our grasp to lass="word-wrap-span">compute on all human-generated information”, and that lass="word-wrap-span">The spooks could lass="word-wrap-span">eavesdrop on every one of lass="word-wrap-span">Their communications and track lass="word-wrap-span">Their smartphones even when lass="word-wrap-span">They were switched off. lass="word-wrap-span">Appalled by lass="word-wrap-span">The power and lass="word-wrap-span">intrusiveness of a mass-surveillance system that had been developed without public lass="word-wrap-span">consent, Mr Snowden says, he began organising one of lass="word-wrap-span">The largest leaks in lass="word-wrap-span">The history of lass="word-wrap-span">American spying.

lass="word-wrap-span">This is Mr Snowden’s account of an lass="word-wrap-span">episode that still provokes powerful emotions. He says mass surveillance directly lass="word-wrap-span">contradicts both the spirit and letter of lass="word-wrap-span">America's constitution, which is designed to protect its lass="word-wrap-span">citizlass="word-wrap-span">ens from an over-mighty government. His lass="word-wrap-span">Former employers decry him as a traitor. lass="word-wrap-span">Western officials have lass="word-wrap-span">alleged that lass="word-wrap-span">China and lass="word-wrap-span">Russia have managed to lass="word-wrap-span">decrypt some of the cache of documents he took, something that, on Mr Snowden's telling, should be impossible. lass="word-wrap-span">For now at least, the truth remains unknowable.

His lass="word-wrap-span">detractors’ most powerful weapon is the fact that Mr Snowden has ended up living in lass="word-wrap-span">Russia. He argues that this is lass="word-wrap-span">America’s fault: the lass="word-wrap-span">State lass="word-wrap-span">Department cancelled Mr Snowden’s passport while he was in the air, en route from lass="word-wrap-span">Hong lass="word-wrap-span">Kong to lass="word-wrap-span">Ecuador, where he planned to apply for lass="word-wrap-span">asylum. lass="word-wrap-span">When he landed in lass="word-wrap-span">Moscow to change planes, that left him unable to move on. Unwilling to return to lass="word-wrap-span">America, because its lass="word-wrap-span">espionage laws prevent public interest being used as a defence in court, he applied for lass="word-wrap-span">asylum to dozlass="word-wrap-span">ens of countries. lass="word-wrap-span">But, he says, all were too worried about lass="word-wrap-span">American reprisals to grant the request, especially after an lass="word-wrap-span">extraordinary incident in which a lass="word-wrap-span">Bolivian plane carrying Evo lass="word-wrap-span">Morales, that country’s president, was forced to land in Austria and searched in case Mr Snowden was on board.

He recounts being met by lass="word-wrap-span">The FSB—lass="word-wrap-span">Russia’s main intelligence agency—and claims he refused to lass="word-wrap-span">cooperate with lass="word-wrap-span">Them. lass="word-wrap-span">But little more is said of lass="word-wrap-span">The events of lass="word-wrap-span">The past six years. lass="word-wrap-span">The book ends in 2013, with Mr Snowden leaving a lass="word-wrap-span">Moscow airport after weeks in limbo, eventually accepting an offer of lass="word-wrap-span">asylum in lass="word-wrap-span">Russia because, he claims, of a lack of any alternative. lass="word-wrap-span">What role, if any, his lass="word-wrap-span">Russian lass="word-wrap-span">handlers had in lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">emergence of his memoir is not specified.

Mr Snowden’s lass="word-wrap-span">critique of government overreach is powerful. lass="word-wrap-span">But whether through his own fault or otherwise, it is one made from a compromising location. lass="word-wrap-span">Whatever his relationship with the lass="word-wrap-span">Russian authorities, and whenever it began, everything he says in “lass="word-wrap-span">Permanent lass="word-wrap-span">Record”—about himself, and about lass="word-wrap-span">America—must be seen through the prism of his lass="word-wrap-span">dependence on the Kremlin. As he admits thinking before he lass="word-wrap-span">ignited the scandal, were he to end up in lass="word-wrap-span">Russia, the lass="word-wrap-span">American government “wouldn’t have to do anything to lass="word-wrap-span">discredit me other than point at a map”.
